items.title: Does the AN0M sting show police need more powers?
items.content:
After three years of uninterrupted eavesdropping on the world's crime networks, a global police operation showed its hand this week. 

The Australian Federal Police, along with the FBI and the EU's Europol, finally pulled back the veil on Operation Ironside. 

They say it's led to hundreds of arrests and netted literally tonnes of drugs, cash, and guns. 

Their methodology has been hailed as ingenious: police accessed an encrypted app called AN0M from the outset, then distributed it to criminals. 

But how much damage does a sting like this do? 

And do Australian police really need the extra powers they're pitching for? 

Featured: 

Dr Teagan Westendorf, Strategic Policing and Law Enforcement Analyst, Australian Strategic Policy Institute

items.title: Asia's cautionary COVID tale for Australia
items.content:
Australia loves to see itself as an international COVID success story, and there's a lot of truth to that.

But we used to have more company — Taiwan, Thailand and Vietnam, just to name a few.

In almost every case, that success has given way to a surge in recent months, as new, highly contagious versions of the virus, like the Delta variant, have spread around the world.

And the parallels with Australia's situation are hard to ignore.

Today on The Signal, it's the cautionary tale for Australia in Asia's latest COVID-19 surge.

Featured:

Mazoe Ford, South East Asia Correspondent, ABC

Professor Nancy Baxter, Epidemiologist, Head of School of Population & Global Health, University of Melbourne

items.title: A plague that won't end
items.content:
Mice are still multiplying in their millions across eastern Australia.

Since September last year, the rodents have been devastating crops, drowning in swimming pools, and now their carcasses are even being coughed up by cod in inland rivers.

So what's driving the outbreak?

And with some drastic measures being considered, will anything bring the plague to an end?

Featured:

Phil Cleal, Forbes resident

Dr Peter Brown, senior research scientist, CSIRO

items.contentSnippet:
Mice are still multiplying in their millions across eastern Australia.

Since September last year, the rodents have been devastating crops, drowning in swimming pools, and now their carcasses are even being coughed up by cod in inland rivers.

So what's driving the outbreak?

And with some drastic measures being considered, will anything bring the plague to an end?

items.title: What's keeping Melbourne in lockdown
items.content:
What began as a circuit-breaker lockdown for Melbourne is now in its second week, as contact tracers try to find the source for two new cases that seemed to appear out of nowhere.

All the while, the theoretical end to lockdown on Friday is approaching, with no-one the wiser as to whether or not it'll be delayed.

Today on The Signal, we're asking what it will take for Melbourne's lockdown to lift.

Featured:

Raf Epstein, ABC Radio Melbourne Drive Host

items.content:
One of the country's biggest surveys shows that most Australians think it's harder for young people to get ahead than it used to be.

So why do people feel that way?

Today on The Signal, we're digging into the trove of information that is the ABC's Australia Talks study.

We hear from young people all over the country, and ask why so many think things are getting worse.

Boris, 25-year-old from South Australia

items.title: What we got wrong about Tiananmen Square
items.content:
Australia has a long history of calling out China for human rights abuses.

This week, during a visit to Queenstown, the prime minister Scott Morrison and his New Zealand counterpart Jacinda Ardern issued a joint statement expressing concerns about abuses in Xinjiang and Hong Kong, prompting a swift and angry response from Beijing.

But there've been other times when Australia hasn't got the facts about China right.

In 1989, after tanks rolled into Tiananmen Square in Beijing and brutally ended weeks of protests, the then prime minister Bob Hawke gave a horrifying description of what Australia thought happened.

But where did the account come from?

And why was it wrong?

Today on The Signal, we sit down with Matt Bevan from the ABC's new podcast China If You're Listening to discuss new information about the massacre, 32 years on.

Featured:

Matt Bevan, Host, China If You're Listening

Blanche d'Alpuget, Biographer and wife of late former prime minister Bob Hawke

Richard Rigby, Emeritus Professor of the College of Asia and the Pacific, Australian National University, Canberra

items.title: Is Australia on track for a pay rise?
items.content:
Australian wages have been stuck for a long time. In fact they've hardly twitched for about a decade now.

The conventional wisdom as to why, is that we had an oversupply of workers, and not enough work for them to do.

So with borders closed to foreign workers, and a number of industries desperate for local ones, what's keeping wages low? And could it be about to change?

Featured:

Sarah Hunter, Chief Economist, BIS Oxford Economics

items.title: Did COVID-19 leak from a lab?
items.content:
At the start of the pandemic, conspiracy theorists pounced on the idea that COVID-19 came from a lab.

At the time the theory was widely panned by scientists, but now it has a new lease on life.

So what is the new information that’s revived the Wuhan lab leak theory?

Today on The Signal, we speak to two of the reporters in the US who have been at the forefront of the global coverage of the COVID-19 pandemic.

What are the gaps in our knowledge of the origins of the virus?

And will we ever get conclusive answers?

Featured: 

Donald G McNeil Jr, former science and public health reporter at The New York Times

Warren Strobel, National Security Reporter at The Wall Street Journal

items.title: Is Victoria's lockdown working?
items.content:
Victorians know life in lockdown better than anybody else in Australia.

On the three previous occasions the state has gone into a lockdown, the measure eventually achieved its aims.

But this time it's a little different, with a new, more infectious variant spreading in the community, and at least one case that’s still a mystery.

So is the lockdown working so far?

And could it drag on past Friday?

Today on The Signal we hear about the successes and pitfalls of the latest iteration of Victoria's COVID strategy, and ask what lessons the state has learned on the way.

Featured: 

Professor Tony Blakely, Professorial Fellow in Epidemiology, Melbourne School of Population and Global Health, University of Melbourne

items.title: Gaza and Israel's uneasy ceasefire
items.content:
The ceasefire in Gaza and Israel is a week old today, and tensions in the region are running hot.

In Gaza, Palestinians mourning those killed by Israeli rockets say daily life is unbearable, and restrictions put in place by Israel make rebuilding impossible.

Across the border, Israelis say they live in fear of more rocket attacks by the Palestinian militant group Hamas, as anger and hatred between Arabs and Jews in the country leads to death and violence.

So can the ceasefire hold?

Today on The Signal, we head to Gaza and Tel Aviv.

We ask whether the causes of the recent fighting that claimed more than 200 lives in Gaza and 13 in Israel have been addressed, and whether peace and justice are now further off in the region than ever.

Featured:

Mosab Abu Toha, Poet and writer, Gaza

Dina Kraft, Journalist and podcast host, Tel Aviv

items.title: Victoria's vaccine wake-up call
items.content:
We still don't have a handle on how big Victoria's COVID outbreak is going to be.

But already the blame-game has started.

From low vaccine take-up rates to contact tracing errors, delays in COVID testing and failures in hotel quarantine, the list of possible culprits is long.

So is one factor more responsible than the others?

And will the outbreak at least jolt people wary of getting vaccinated to roll up their sleeves?

Featured:

David Speers, Host, ABC TV Insiders

items.title: Are we getting better at treating COVID-19?
items.content:
It's been 11 months since a big COVID-19 outbreak in Melbourne threw the city into lockdown.

Now, the virus is again spreading in the city's suburbs, with new cases in the west and north.

So have we got better at treating patients with COVID?

Today on The Signal, we take stock of how COVID-19 treatments have evolved over time.

We ask what hurdles remain, and what new options might be on the way.

Featured:

Tegan Taylor, ABC Health and Science Reporter and Co-host, ABC Coronacast

items.title: Must the Games really go on?
items.content:
The Tokyo Olympic Games have already been delayed once.

Now, eight weeks from the opening ceremony, opinion polls show most people in Japan want them scrapped altogether.

But the International Olympic Committee is barrelling forward, insisting the Games must go on.

So how can officials, athletes and their supporters have confidence they won't be a disaster?

Today on The Signal, we speak to Tokyo-bound ABC sports reporter Tracey Holmes about how Japan is preparing for the least popular Games in history.

Featured:

Tracey Holmes, Host, ABC The Ticket

items.title: What went wrong with the vaccine rollout
items.content:
So far Australia's COVID-19 vaccine program has not been a success.

Our early vaccine bets didn't pay off, the rollout strategy has been overhauled once already, we've missed all the deadlines we set for ourselves at the start, and with less than 7 percent of the community having received two shots, herd immunity remains a mirage.

So how did this happen?

Today on The Signal, we sit down with the ABC's 4 Corners team to investigate all the ways Australia's vaccination program has fallen short

What are the main factors that led us here?

And how do the architects of the scheme account for its failures?

Featured:

Adam Harvey, Reporter, ABC TV 4 Corners

Professor Brendan Murphy, Department of Health Secretary and former Chief Medical Officer 2016-2020

Greg Hunt, Health Minister

Dr Norman Swan, Host, ABC RN The Health Report and Co-host, ABC Coronacast

Jane Halton, Former Department of Health Secretary 2002-2014

Dr Nathan Pinskier, Melbourne GP

Senator Rex Patrick, Independent Senator for South Australia

Dr John Gerard, Head of Infectious Diseases, Gold Coast University Hospital

items.title: Is raiding your super ever a good idea?
items.content:
When getting your first housing deposit together feels impossible, raiding $50,000 from your super fund is tempting.

But is it a good idea?

Since 2017, it's been possible to dip into your super to get you over the line, and in the budget last week, the rules changed again.

Now you can draw up to $50,000 from your retirement fund to help you buy your very own patch of land.

Today on The Signal, what's the best way to use your super?

And what could this scheme do to Australia's already hypercharged housing market?

Featured:

Jane Norman, Political Reporter, ABC

James Kirby, Wealth Editor, The Australian

items.title: Do we really need a new gas power plant?
items.content:
It started with an ultimatum, and it's ending in a new gas-fired power plant.

The Government is making the case for the new project at Kurri Kurri, in the NSW Hunter region.

In fact, they're so sold on the idea, they're stumping up $600 million to build it.

It was supposed to replace the Liddell coal-fired power station when it closes in two years, but many voices in the energy industry claim other kinds of power will easily fill that need.

The Government on the other hand is promising a new gas plant will ensure a more reliable and cheap source of power.

So does Australia really need a new gas fired power station, and is it a good deal for taxpayers?

Featured:

David Speers, Host, ABC Insiders

items.title: 39 questions that could save your life
items.content:
If you're a victim of domestic violence, and you go to police, that can yield a whole range of responses — from urgent to unconcerned.

A lot of the time, how you're treated comes down to the individual judgement of whichever officer you end up speaking to.

But in Victoria, they're trying something different. And it's working.

Today on The Signal, we look at the data-driven algorithmic approach that's taking the guesswork and bias out of how police respond to domestic violence in one state.

So could it work elsewhere?

Featured:

Hayley Gleeson, Domestic & Family Violence Reporter, ABC

items.title: Why Israel and Gaza are on a knife edge
items.content:
The fighting between Israel and Palestinians is more intense than it has been for years.

Israeli troops have amassed at Gaza's border, with fears of an all out war.

An escalation in anger over Israel's occupation of Palestinian territories, and a spate of evictions, has led to rocket fire from Hamas militants in Gaza and waves of airstrikes being launched by Israeli forces.

And it's not just conflict at the border. Inside the country, Israel's political leaders are warning that violent street clashes between Jews and Arabs could mutate into a larger civil conflict.

So is there a path back from the brink of war?

Featured:

Stephen Farrell, Reuters Bureau Chief for Israel and the Palestinian Territories
items.contentSnippet:
The fighting between Israel and Palestinians is more intense than it has been for years.

Israeli troops have amassed at Gaza's border, with fears of an all out war.

An escalation in anger over Israel's occupation of Palestinian territories, and a spate of evictions, has led to rocket fire from Hamas militants in Gaza and waves of airstrikes being launched by Israeli forces.

And it's not just conflict at the border. Inside the country, Israel's political leaders are warning that violent street clashes between Jews and Arabs could mutate into a larger civil conflict.

So is there a path back from the brink of war?

Featured:

Stephen Farrell, Reuters Bureau Chief for Israel and the Palestinian Territories

items.title: Getting ready to open 'Fortress Australia'
items.content:
Lowering the drawbridge on 'Fortress Australia' is shaping up to be a logistical nightmare.

According to an estimate in last week's federal budget, the process could begin by the middle of next year.

But there's a lot of work to do before then.

So will we be ready in time? And what's still standing in our way?

Featured:

Professor Catherine Bennett, Chair in Epidemiology, Deakin University

items.content:
The satellite business is booming.

From state-sponsored spy tech, through to machines the size of a postage stamp, companies and nations are launching them all at an unprecedented rate.

In fact without them, the world as we know it would grind to a halt.

Today on The Signal, the wild west of the new space race, and what's at stake.

Featured:

Dr Brad Tucker, Astrophysicist, ANU

Steve Winnall, VP Engineering, Myriota

items.title: Annabel Crabb reviews the 'women's budget'
items.content:
The government desperately wanted to impress women with this federal budget, and shore up votes before the next election.

The Treasurer Josh Frydenberg announced new spending on aged care, child care and disability support, not to mention $1 billion in support for women's safety.

So was it really a "women's budget"?

And if it was, what do women actually get?

Featured:

items.title: Your federal budget cheat sheet
items.content:
The Federal Government has just handed down what is most likely its last budget before the next election.

It's a pretty odd one, because the budget is in much better shape than even the Government was expecting just a few months ago.

But instead of pocketing all the cash for budget repair, the Treasurer Josh Frydenberg is spreading it around on everything from aged care to micro-breweries.

Today on The Signal, has the Coalition had a fundamental economic conversion? Or is this budget all about the upcoming election?

Featured:
Ian Verrender, ABC Business Editor

items.title: Do we need a 'people's vaccine'?
items.content:
As rich countries return to normal, COVID-19 is still spreading in developing countries worldwide.

In places including India and Brazil, thousands are dying each day while vaccination programs stall.

So can the world manufacture doses faster?

Today on The Signal, there's a mounting case for the world to scrap patent protections for COVID-19 vaccines to allow more countries to manufacture their own.

It would involve temporarily waiving something called the TRIPS agreement, and the US and Australia are both now onboard.

So is it going to happen?

And will it solve the global vaccine crisis?

Featured: 

Professor Ronald Labonte, Canada Research Chair in Contemporary Globalisation and Health Equity, School of Epidemiology and Public Health, University of Ottawa, Canada

items.title: Keeping mum about being transgender
items.content:
There's a fight going on in New South Wales right now about whether transgender people can be acknowledged in schools.

The bill would ban the mention or teaching of what it terms "gender fluidity".

And if you zoom out, globally, the argument bears a very close resemblance to a swathe of bills being tabled and sometimes passed in states across America.

Today on the Signal, the new battles facing trans people here and the US laws inspiring them.

Featuring:

Ashleigh Raper, New South Wales State Political Reporter, ABC

Teddy Cook, Vice President, Australian Professional Association for Trans Health

items.title: Can the budget fix aged care?
items.content:
Australia's aged care system is deeply broken.

Over two and a half years, a royal commission into its failures heard harrowing stories of abuse and neglect, both often linked to chronic understaffing.

Two months ago, after the royal commission handed down its final report, the federal government acknowledged there were "fundamental issues" that needed to be addressed.

So is it going to address them in next week's budget?

Today on The Signal, we hear what the royal commission said needed to change, and ask whether there's the political will to follow that through.

Featured:

Jude, aged care worker

Anne Connolly, Reporter, ABC Investigations

items.title: How flying home became a crime
items.content:
Remember when Barnaby Joyce threatened to have Johnny Depp's dogs put down?

Australia's Biosecurity Act gives ministers sweeping powers, from euthanising celebrity pets to slamming shut the nation's borders and forcing all arrivals into mandatory quarantine.

This week, the government's interpretation of its powers under the Act went even further, when it issued a sweeping ban on Australians in India from trying to come home.

So is it a step too far?

Today on The Signal, with the ban on re-entry from India currently being challenged in court, we dig into the law under which the order was made, and ask whether this decision reflects a permanent change of heart on how to keep Australians safe.

Featured:

David Speers, Host, Insiders, ABC TV

items.title: How would war with China play out?
items.content:
In the space of a month or so, war with China has gone from being the stuff of paranoid science fiction plots to a serious political topic.

But how seriously should the rest of us take it?

Today on The Signal, we ask why we're suddenly discussing a war with the world's biggest military.

And if it ever did happen, how would our own military strength and the strength of our allies measure up?

Featured:

Dr Bates Gill, Professor of Asia Pacific Security Studies at Macquarie University

items.title: Is India downplaying its COVID crisis?
items.content:
India is facing the world's worst COVID crisis yet.

Hospitals are running out of oxygen and bodies are being burnt in the street.

The country is now recording 400,000 new infections per day, and Australia has slammed shut the border for at least the next two weeks.

So why does India's Government seem to be aggressively playing the crisis down?

Featured:

James Oaten, ABC South Asia Correspondent, Delhi

Dr Arun N. Madhavan, medical consultant, Quality Clinic, Palakkad, Kerala

Katie Bhagat, Australian traveller in India

Dr Farah Husain, critical care specialist, Lok Nayak Jai Prakash Narayan Hospital, Delhi

items.title: When the game plays you
items.content:
About two thirds of Australians are gamers of some kind, although not everyone realises it.

It's one of the industries that did incredibly well out of COVID-19.

It also happens to be one of the most manipulative and under regulated.

So what are the tricks of the multi-billion-dollar trade that get you playing longer and spending more, possibly without you even noticing?

Featured:

Lucy Carter, Reporter, ABC Four Corners

Ron Curry, Interactive Games & Entertainment Association

Dr Daniel King, Gaming Researcher, Flinders University

Dr James Sauer, Gaming Researcher, University of Tasmania

items.title: Can Papi G survive Australia's wildest election?
items.content:
Tasmania's bizarre election campaign has had a bit of everything.

From unsolicited explicit images to candidates dumping on their own parties' policies and a premier known to TikTok as Papi G, it's been a chaotic few weeks.

And it could be about to get weirder: there's a very real chance the winner will resign.

Today on The Signal we dig into the crazy, and ask what voters will make of it all tomorrow.

Featured:

Emily Baker, ABC Tasmanian State Political Reporter

items.title: What happened to budget repair?
items.content:
Two years isn't really that much time.

But in politics, it may as well be two decades, and when you throw in a pandemic, it's basically eternity.

In 2019, the Treasurer Josh Frydenerg used to talk up a budget surplus often and loudly, before COVID-19 forced him to spend up big to stave off economic disaster.

So with an election on the horizon, will Josh Frydenberg return to the surplus goal?

Or will politics get in the way?

Featured:

David Speers, Host, Insiders, ABC TV

items.title: Mining our way to net zero
items.content:
There's an uncomfortable reality about reaching net zero that's not often discussed.

It's that getting there might mean a whole lot more environmentally challenging mining.

At a virtual summit of leaders last week, everyone agreed the days of coal, oil and gas were numbered, and wind, solar and batteries were the key to the future.

So where are we going to get the raw materials to build them?

Today on The Signal, we look at the mining boom we're going to need for the energy transition, and ask whether we're ready for the new environmental and human challenges it could create.

Featured:
 ‪Dr Eleonore Lebre, Research Fellow, Sustainable Minerals Institute, University of Queensland

items.title: Beyond the brink: India's COVID catastrophe
items.content:
India is facing the world's worst coronavirus wave to date, with more than 330,000 new cases daily.

Hospitals are swamped, morgues and crematoriums overwhelmed, and a shortage of oxygen has left COVID patients dying in ICUs.

More than 15,000 Indians died from COVID last week, and experts concede the real toll is much higher.

So in a place that had so many early successes, how did it all unravel?

Today on The Signal, how India got here, and what comes next.

Featured:

James Oaten, ABC South Asia correspondent

Dr Harjit Singh Bhatti, Manipal Hospital Dwarka, Delhi

Dr Deepak Baid, Association of Medical Consultants, Mumbai

Barkha Dutt, Independent Indian journalist

items.title: Teenagers review the milkshake consent video
items.content:
The government-funded 'milkshake' consent videos have arguably launched more memes than meaningful realisations.

Commentators, experts, and social media users tore them to shreds almost as soon as they were released, and they've since been pulled.

But what do teenagers make of them?

Today on The Signal, we ask the target audience for this campaign what they think, what they would prefer, and what their lived reality is when it comes to consent.

Featured:
James, 19-year-old
Alexa, 17-year-old

items.title: Will George Floyd's murder change America?
items.content:
It took the jury just 10 hours to deliver the verdict the world has been waiting for.

After a three-week trial, 12 Minneapolis jurors found ex-police officer Derek Chauvin guilty of the murder of George Floyd.

It was a murder that inspired a protest movement that spread from Minneapolis across America, and within weeks its rallying cries were heard worldwide.

So now the verdict is in, what comes next?

Today on The Signal, we talk about what happened to George Floyd last year, what next for his killer, and what the case means for the future of policing in America.

Featured:

Nina Moini, Reporter, Minnesota Public Radio, Minneapolis

items.title: Is the Australian military 'too woke'?
items.content:
The Government has had more than usual to say about the Australian military lately, and if you've been listening, you might have noticed a distinct shift in rhetoric.

Back in November, after the release of a war crimes report which found Australian soldiers had murdered 39 Afghan civilians, the ADF underwent a very public 'dark night of the soul'.

Recently though, we've heard reminders that the core business of the military is to kill, albeit in a legitimate combat setting.

Along with that, there's been a suggestion that the organisation has become too "woke".

Today on the Signal, we examine the reality of ADF culture. Does it need to change, and if so, how?

Featured: 
David Kilcullen, military strategist & counterinsurgency expert, Professor, Arizona State University &  University of New South Wales, Canberra

items.title: What's the price of rejoining the world?
items.content:
Australia is the land which COVID forgot, but there's no chance it can stay that way.

As of this week, we're in a travel bubble with New Zealand, and more countries will follow.

But the price of admission in the long term is giving up our run of zeros

Today on the Signal, what comes after New Zealand? And are we ready for the consequences?

Featured:

Professor Tony Blakely, Epidemiologist, University of Melbourne

items.title: Should Scientology lose its tax free status?
items.content:
The Church of Scientology has always been controversial and it may be about to come under fresh scrutiny.

Australian law still considers Scientology a religion and as a result, it enjoys tax free status here.

Now, some Australian politicians say it's time for an inquiry into whether or not that's fair. 

Featured:
Steve Cannane, ABC reporter and author of Fair Game: The Incredible Untold Story of Scientology in Australia

Andrew Leigh, Shadow Assistant Minister for Treasury and Charities

items.title: Why vaccines haven't halted COVID in the US
items.content:
America's luck when it comes to COVID-19 seems to have changed, and then changed back again.

US President Joe Biden made it very clear from the outset that handling the pandemic was number one on his to do list.

But after some early wins against the virus, COVID transmission is on the rise again.

So what's gone wrong? And can Biden turn it around before it becomes a fourth wave?

Featured:

Dan Diamond, National Health Reporter, The Washington Post

items.title: 30 more years of deaths in custody
items.content:
30 years ago to the day, a royal commission into Indigenous deaths in custody handed its findings down.

Since then, at least 450 more First Nations people have died while on the inside, and with at least five of those deaths recorded just last month, it's clear many of the problems of three decades ago remain.

So what, if anything, has changed?

Today on The Signal, we hear from those whose anguish provided the impetus for the original inquiry.

Do they think anything has improved, or was the three-year-long inquiry all that time ago in vain?

Featured:

Isabella Higgins, ABC Indigenous Affairs reporter

Glen Boney, brother of Lloyd Boney

Belinda Boney, sister of Lloyd Boney

Meena Singh, Legal Director, Human Rights Law Centre

Chris McHughes, Brewarrina resident

items.title: From Cartier watches to bullying claims
items.content:
It started with a public row about Cartier watches.

Late last year, the former CEO of Australia Post Christine Holgate stood aside after her decision to give four Cartier watches as gifts to senior executives was loudly criticised by dozens of politicians from the prime minister Scott Morrison down.

Now, Ms Holgate is hitting back, claiming she was bullied and humiliated out of a job that she loved, and arguing that a man in her position would never have faced the same treatment.

So what exactly did Christine Holgate say?

And what does it mean for the Government's new focus on improving workplaces for women?

Today on The Signal we review the fireworks show from Parliament yesterday, find out what it was that lit the fuse, and ask what happens now.

Featured:

Stephanie Borys, ABC Parliament House Political Reporter

items.title: What drives male sexual aggression
items.content:
There's a loud question echoing in Australians' minds, as the country has its belated #MeToo moment.

The big question is 'why?'. What drives that behaviour?

Today on The Signal, we speak to a criminologist who's followed the breadcrumbs back, in an attempt to find out: what fuels male sexual aggression?

And can the answer, no matter how uncomfortable, help us find solutions?

Featured:

Dr Xanthe Mallet, Criminologist, University of Newcastle

items.title: How worried should you be about AstraZeneca?
items.content:
Australia's vaccine strategy was already in trouble, but in the past few days things got worse.

The AstraZeneca vaccine at the centre of our rollout is now no longer recommended for anyone under 50, while the only alternative currently in production, Pfizer, can only be made overseas.

So how much trouble are we in?

Today on The Signal, we give you the A to Z on AstraZeneca.

How big is the blood clot risk?

Has Australia made the right call?

And how big a hole does this blow in the roadmap back to normal?

Featured:

Dr Kylie Quinn, Vice Chancellor's Research Fellow, School of Health and Biomedical Science, RMIT University, Melbourne

items.title: Has the Government worked out what women want?
items.content:
One in three working Australians report being sexually harassed at work, and this week the Government came up with some solutions.

It's been a long road — they've been sitting on a major report they commissioned on the topic for more than a year, and released their formal response this week.

The Attorney-General Michaelia Cash says they'll agree to all 55 recommendations either in full or in part, with legislation to follow.

So what's the fine print? And will it make a real difference in the workplace?

Featured:

Karen O'Connell, Associate Professor of Law, University of Technology Sydney, specialising in sex discrimination

items.title: Are we replacing coal power fast enough?
items.content:
Australia's coal fired power plants are on borrowed time.

The Northern power plant at Port Augusta in South Australia was reduced to rubble in 2017, and Hazelwood in Victoria's LaTrobe Valley went the same way last year.

Next in line is Liddell in New South Wales, slated for decommissioning in 2023.

This month marks the deadline the Federal Government gave the energy industry to make a plan for a world without Liddell and create 1000MW of new power, or it would fund a new gas-fired power station.

So has the industry filled the gap yet?

And what happens the next time a coal-fired power station shuts?

Featured:

Tristan Edis, Director, Green Energy Markets

items.title: Floods and COVID: Timor Leste's twin crises
items.content:
The people of Timor Leste woke up on Sunday morning to an extraordinary situation: large parts of their capital, Dili, were underwater.

On Saturday morning, the skies opened, and the rain didn't stop until Sunday afternoon.

It was so heavy and unrelenting that much of the city's downtown region, including the presidential palace, the national hospital, and thousands of homes, was inundated.

The floods came at the exact moment that the country was scrambling to control a major COVID outbreak.

Today on The Signal, Timor Leste's worst floods since the 1970s, and what it means for their knife edge moment in the pandemic.
Featured:

Raimundos Oki, journalist, Timor Leste

Dr Jeremy Beckett, GP and Director of health NGO Maluk Timor

items.title: Solving the never-ending work day
items.content:
Australians work some of the longest hours in the developed world, and for plenty of people the job doesn't finish when they leave the office.

Now at one workplace in Australia, employees and their union are saying enough is enough.

They've incorporated a 'right to disconnect' into their contracts.

So what does that mean in practice?

And could it work for you?

Featured:

Daniel Ziffer, Reporter, ABC TV The Business

Sergeant Rachel Dunkinson, Victoria Police

Wayne Gatt, Secretary, Police Association of Victoria

Danni Hunter, Victorian Executive Director, Property Council of Australia

Professor Emmanuel Josserand, Centre for Business and Social Innovation, University of Technology Sydney

items.title: Meet the Stranded Australians
items.content:
No home, no flight, dwindling medical supplies and a depleted bank account.

We're following two of the many thousands of Australians currently stranded overseas.

Affordable flights home are still vanishingly rare, with a strict cap on international arrivals, so the quarantine system isn’t overwhelmed.

So what do you do when you’re stuck on the wrong side of the world during a pandemic?

Featured:
Liz & Matt, Australians in London

items.title: How to get through family lunch
items.content:
If you're seeing family this weekend, you could well be girding your loins for some sort of argument around the dinner table.

It's hard to find a family without political or ideological divides, and they're often along a generational lines.

Today on the Signal, we're looking at one family's approach to navigating those disagreements and giving you some practical advice on how to handle your own.


Featured:

Georgie, daughter

Peter, father

Dr Charlotte Keating, clinical psychologist specialising in families

items.title: Inside PNG's COVID-19 crisis
items.content:
Papua New Guinea's COVID-19 crisis is spiralling out of control.

In just three weeks, the country has recorded 3,000 new cases, and clinics and field hospitals are struggling to keep up with demand.

It has the potential to become a full-blown humanitarian crisis.

Today on The Signal, we hear how the situation in PNG became so bad, so fast, and ask whether Australia is doing enough to help.

Featured:

Natalie Whiting, ABC Papua New Guinea Correspondent

Dr Gary Nou, Emergency Physician, Rita Flynn temporary field hospital and Gerehu General Hospital, Port Moresby

Dr Osborne Liko, Health Secretary, Papua New Guinea Ministry of Health

Dr Paki Malumi, Chief Executive, Port Moresby General Hospital

items.title: Exposing the Luna Park cover-up
items.content:
In 1979 at Luna Park in Sydney, the ghost train caught fire.

It killed seven people, and police at the time were quick to blame an electrical fault.

But there were always whispers of something else at play: could it have been arson? If so, who would do such a thing? And did the police investigation at the time and the other subsequent inquiries go deep enough?

Today on The Signal, we sit down with ABC investigative reporter Caro Meldrum-Hanna to hear some of the answers.

What have Caro and her colleagues unearthed?

And who was it that made sure this stayed buried for so long?

Featured:

Caro Meldrum-Hanna, Reporter, ABC TV + iView, 'Exposed: The Ghost Train Fire'
items.contentSnippet:
In 1979 at Luna Park in Sydney, the ghost train caught fire.

It killed seven people, and police at the time were quick to blame an electrical fault.

But there were always whispers of something else at play: could it have been arson? If so, who would do such a thing? And did the police investigation at the time and the other subsequent inquiries go deep enough?

Today on The Signal, we sit down with ABC investigative reporter Caro Meldrum-Hanna to hear some of the answers.

What have Caro and her colleagues unearthed?

And who was it that made sure this stayed buried for so long?

Featured:

Caro Meldrum-Hanna, Reporter, ABC TV + iView, 'Exposed: The Ghost Train Fire'

items.title: Is Australia botching the vaccine rollout?
items.content:
Six million Australians are eligible for the COVID-19 vaccine, but as of Monday, fewer than 600,000 have had it.

For many countries, the hold up has been the international supply chain, but that's not the case here.

Today on The Signal, we investigate the slow start to Australia's COVID-19 vaccine program.

Is it time to admit there's a problem? And either way, how do we speed it up?

Featured:

Dr Stephen Duckett, Health Economist & Director, Health Program, The Grattan Institute

Dr Karen Price, President, Royal Australasian College of General Practitioners




Editor's Note: A statement from a spokesperson for Health Minister Greg Hunt was received after this podcast was recorded, a link to a related story has been included within the episode description.

https://www.abc.net.au/news/2021-03-30/covid-rollout-logistical-effort-to-ramp-up-vaccination/100026116

items.title: Is the NDIS changing for the better?
items.content:
Nearly half a million Australians living with a disability have been put on notice.

The National Disability Insurance Scheme, which they rely on for support, is going to change.

The Federal Government says it's about making the scheme fairer for everyone.

But is that really the full picture?

Today on The Signal, what the Government is planning to do to the NDIS, and what it means for people living with a disability.

Featured:

Nas Campanella, ABC Disability Affairs Reporter

Aaron Carpenter, disability services provider and NDIS participant

items.title: Inside a far-right recruitment drive in Australia
items.content:
Hours of secret recordings obtained by the ABC show that a global neo-Nazi group is recruiting in Australia.

'The Base' has been grooming young men who espouse racist views to join them, and in Perth, it seems to have had some success.

Today on The Signal, we hear the audio of the prospective recruits.

What inspires the extremism of the group?

And should it and others like it be declared terrorist organisations in Australia?

Featured:

Alex Mann, Reporter, ABC Background Briefing

Jason Wilson, US-based Australian journalist

Dr Anne Aly, Labor MP and professor specialising in extremism and counter-terrorism

Dean Smith, former political candidate, Pauline Hanson’s One Nation Party

items.title: Coping with the floods of the future
items.content:
The floods in NSW and QLD are both déjà vu and a taste of worse to come, if climate change forecasts are accurate.

The question is, how much of the damage suffered by the worst affected communities is avoidable?

Today on the Signal, we're asking how our town and cities could change to cope with the next round of record breaking floods, when they inevitably arrive.

Featured:

Graham Creed, ABC weather specialist and meteorologist

Barbara Norman, Professor of Urban and Regional Planning, University of Canberra

items.title: Scott Morrison's glass houses
items.content:
There was palpable tension in the Blue Room of Parliament House when Scott Morrison stood up to speak yesterday.

At the outset of the press conference, it was clear his tone on the topic has shifted dramatically, but within minutes, he'd hit back at journalists' question with a warning: be careful.

Editor's note: The Prime Minister issued a late night apology on his Facebook page after claiming during a press conference that News Corporation was dealing with its own harassment complaint, a claim rejected by the company. In his post, Mr Morrison said: "I accept their account. I was wrong to raise it, the emotion of the moment is no excuse."

Featured:
Olivia Caisley, Federal Politics Reporter, The Australian

items.title: Do we need a minister for loneliness?
items.content:
COVID-19 lockdowns and border closures have meant a lot more of us than usual have recent experiences of feeling lonely

And now, with a new group being set up in the Parliament, loneliness finally, officially, has some friends

Today on The Signal, how big a problem has loneliness become?

And what are its new companions planning to do about it?

Featured:

Dr Michelle Lim, Chair, 'Ending Loneliness Together' and Head, Social Health and Wellbeing Laboratory, Swinburne University, Melbourne

Andrew Giles, Labor MP

Dr Fiona Martin, Liberal MP

items.title: How secure is our vaccine supply?
items.content:
From today, 6 million more Australians are eligible for the COVID-19 vaccine.

But with Italy already blocking the export of 250,000 doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine to Australia, and the European Union threatening to block more, will Australia's rollout be delayed?

Today on The Signal, how worried should Australia be about possible kinks in the vaccine supply chain?

And with literally billions of people worldwide also in the vaccine queue, is there a way to get the vaccine made more quickly, and fairly?

Featured:

Dr Deborah Gleeson, Associate Professor, School of Psychology and Public Health, La Trobe University, Melbourne

items.title: How funerals are changing
items.content:
Funerals in Australia are changing.

The death rituals of past generations aren't necessarily the right fit for people dying today, or for those of us whose deaths are hopefully further away.

Today on The Signal, we hear about the trends, and about the funerals of the future.

From body-composting to bushland burials, water-based cremations and funerals without a ceremony at all, what are the options?

And if you're relatively fit and healthy today, how much forward planning can you do?

Featured:

Dr Margaret Gibson, Senior Lecturer, Griffith Centre for Social and Cultural Research, Brisbane

Amy Sagar, General Manager, Tender Funerals

Philip Shelley, CEO, Canberra Cemeteries

Michelle Dariol, Canberra Cemeteries

items.title: Europe's AstraZeneca freakout
items.content:
More than a dozen countries have paused their rollout of the AstraZeneca vaccine, mostly in Europe.

Australia isn't among them, and as of Monday the jab will be offered to a pool of more than 6 million people here.

But Australians themselves are, in some cases, feeling rattled by the news about the pause overseas.

So what's got half of Europe spooked about this one vaccine?

And what's the knock-on effect for us?

Featured:

Professor Julie Leask, Sydney Nursing School, Faculty of Medicine and Health, Adjunct Professor, School of Public Health, Visiting Fellow, National Centre for Immunisation Research and Surveillance



Editor's note: Since recording this podcast the European Medicines Agency (EMA) says it has found a possible link between AstraZeneca's COVID-19 vaccine and rare blood clotting issues in adults.

items.title: What's beyond the JobKeeper cliff?
items.content:
The verdict is unanimous: JobKeeper kept Australia afloat during the COVID-19 recession.

But all good things must come to an end. Specifically, two weeks from today.

So what's on the other side?

Today on The Signal, the world beyond the JobKeeper cliff.

Which businesses will survive, and which ones will become casualties of COVID-19?

Featured: 

Stephanie Chalmers, ABC news business reporter

Sonia Ortega, Chief executive, Global Experience

Leanne Harwood, Managing director for Australasia and Japan, InterContinental Hotels Group

Gus Fernandez, Bookings manager, Gilligan's Hotel and Resort, Cairns

Vanessa Schap, Tourism consultant, Gilligan's Hotel and Resort, Cairns

items.title: Are these women's marches different?
items.content:
We've been here before.

Thousands of women took to the streets on Monday to demand a safer world, free from gendered violence.

This time though, their voices were louder and more determined than they have been in a long while.

So will the result this time be different?

Jess Hill, journalist and author, 'Look What You Made Me Do'

items.title: Surviving Syria's 10 years of war
items.content:
Over the past decade, the lives of millions of people in Syria have been turned upside down.

From bombings to beheadings, Syria has been utterly destroyed by hatred and violence.

Since March 2011, 600,000 people have died, 2 million have been injured and 13.7 million have lost their homes.

So how has the conflict gone on for so long?

And as it drags into its eleventh year, what are the reflections of those whose lives it has destroyed?



Featured:

Tracey Shelton, Reporter, ABC Asia Pacific newsroom

Amina Srio, Syrian-Australian

Jessie Adam, Syrian-Australian

Jezeel Adam, Syrian-Australian

items.title: Truth telling in Arnhem Land
items.content:
The people of Arnhem Land are having a conversation that could radically re-shape Australia.

In the Top End of the Northern Territory, they're discussing the ugliest parts of colonisation, what's happened since, and the way forward from here.

Today on The Signal, we go on the road with the Northern Territory's Treaty Commissioner Mick Dodson.

What are communities telling him?

And how far off is self-determination for Australia's first peoples?

Featured:

Jane Bardon, ABC reporter, Darwin newsroom

Mick Dodson, Northern Territory Treaty Commissioner

items.title: Are COVID-19 variants outpacing vaccines?
items.content:
COVID-19 was expected to mutate slowly, but a year into the pandemic, we've lost track of how many new variants there are.

Scientists are still working out whether the vaccines that we're only just rolling out now will be an effective shield against them.

Today on The Signal, we're taking stock of how COVID-19 is changing, and what weapons we have against the newest versions of it.

So is the virus outpacing vaccine technology, and if it is, then how will Australia ever open up its borders?

Featured:

Dr Norman Swan, ABC Health Report & Coronavirus podcast

items.title: How COVID created unbeatable politicians
items.content:
COVID-19 has done something strange to Australian politics.

The WA Premier Mark McGowan is facing this weekend's election with a 90% approval rating, and the opposition has conceded defeat before polls have opened.

Campaigning to win an election from the top job has always been a big advantage, but this is new territory.

So does the same rule apply to Scott Morrison, and will he test it out before the end of the year?

Featured:

Jacob Kagi, ABC State Political Reporter, WA

Phil Coorey, Political Editor, Australian Financial Review

items.title: Convincing people to get the jab
items.content:
Most people can't wait to get a COVID-19 vaccine, but new research found that more than a quarter of Australians feel the opposite way.

The Government's answer so far has been to set up a COVID-19 Myth Busting unit.

So what will it take to talk millions of vaccine-hesitant Australians over the line?

Or will our scepticism stand in the way of herd immunity?
Featured:

Associate Professor Holly Seale, University of New South Wales, behavioural scientist specialising in infectious disease and vaccines

Professor Richard Osborne. He's director of Global Health and Equity at Swinburne University

items.title: How JobKeeper landed in some rich pockets
items.content:
JobKeeper was supposed to go to the hardest hit corners of the economy.

It’s the program widely credited with keeping us from economic disaster but it’s also had some unintended consequences.

Some companies that accessed the subsidy went on to turn substantial profits and are being called out for using government money to pay out big dividends to shareholders.

It’s not against the rules, but is it right?



Featured: 

Gareth Hutchens, ABC business reporter

items.title: Weren't house prices meant to fall?
items.content:
A year ago, as COVID-19 spread worldwide, the smart money was on property prices taking a hit.

But 12 months on, prices are rising faster than ever, with no sign of a slowdown in sight.

In February, the market recorded the biggest monthly price gain in 17 years.

So if the biggest disruption in a generation doesn't cause house prices to drop, could anything?

And what does all the heat mean for renters trying to buy their first home?



Featured:

Adelaide Timbrell, Economist, ANZ Research

items.title: Christian Porter's emphatic denial
items.content:
As far as denials go, this one was emphatic, strenuous and categorical.

The Attorney-General Christian Porter told a press conference in Perth yesterday that he never had sexual relations with a 16-year-old girl he met at a debating event in Sydney 33 years ago, when he was 17.

She has accused him of rape.

The woman who made the allegation took her own life last year, and police in NSW have wrapped up their inquiry.

So is that the end of the matter?

Today on The Signal, as calls grow louder for further investigations, what will happen next?



Featured:

Patricia Karvelas, Host, ABC RN Drive and Afternoon Briefing, ABC News Channel

items.title: Busting myths about Chinese Australians
items.content:
The relationship between China and Australia is still in the pits, and there's deep suspicion here about Chinese influence campaigns.

So where does that leave Chinese Australians?

Today on The Signal, the scrutiny, and sometimes violence faced by members of the Chinese diaspora in Australia.

How they're treated and how they see not only themselves, but the actions of each country.

Featured:

Dr Jennifer Hsu, Research Fellow, Lowy Institute

Natasha Kassam, Director, Foreign Policy and Public Opinion Program, Lowy Institute

items.title: Will $500 million cure aged care?
items.content:
Aged care in Australia needs to be rebuilt.

That's the recommendation contained in the final report of a royal commission that's spent years looking into the system's failings.

Released yesterday, the commissioners found a system "besieged by neglect" that leaves older Australians stuck on wait lists for years or abandoned them in care facilities set up to maximise profits.

All told, they make 148 recommendations for change.

But is anything going to improve?

Today on The Signal, we ask whether our aged care system can be fixed so it provides the care most of us will eventually need.

Featured:
Norman Hermant, ABC Social Affairs Correspondent

items.title: Another episode about alleged rape and politicians
items.content:
There's a bipartisan meltdown underway when it comes to sexual assault.

On Friday it was the Coalition, with an anonymous letter accusing a cabinet Minister of raping a 16-year-old girl, back in 1988 before he entered Parliament.

Then late on Sunday, a Liberal Senator forwarded an allegation about a Labor MP to the Federal Police.

The Coalition is choosing carefully how to respond to this new allegation, and for the first time this year, Labor is in the same position.

So will the Government out the Minister in question, or hope the storm passes it by?

Featured:

Andrew Probyn, ABC Political Editor

items.title: What Brittany Higgins started
items.content:
Australia has been transfixed by the story of Brittany Higgins for almost a fortnight.

The former political staffer alleges she was raped in a minister's office inside Parliament House in 2019, and has now filed a formal complaint with police.

More allegations from other women against the man she named have followed, along with ongoing rounds of recriminations about how badly the case was handled, all giving rise to the clear impression that something is very wrong in Parliament House.

So is anything going to change?

Today on The Signal, we look into the case that might just trigger some desperately needed reform for women in Australian politics.



Featured:

Clare Armstrong, National Political Reporter, The Daily Telegraph, Parliament House, Canberra

items.title: What Indian farmers are protesting about
items.content:
India is a nation of farmers, and right now many are worried new laws will drive them out of business.

For months now, tens of thousands have been camping out on the outskirts of Delhi protesting against new laws which the Indian Government says will increase profits and create growth.

So what are the farmers worried about?

And is there more driving the laws than first meets the eye?

Today on The Signal, we hear about what it's like to be a farmer in India, and ask why so many fear the new laws could leave them destitute.



Featured:

Kavitha Kuruganti, Founder-Convenor, Alliance for Sustainable and Holistic Agriculture, Delhi

James Oaten, ABC South Asia Correspondent, Delhi

items.title: No jab, no job?
items.content:
The COVID-19 vaccination program is finally here, with the first Australians receiving a jab on Sunday.

It's a staged rollout, with the most vulnerable at the front of the queue.

But despite clear evidence supporting the vaccines, some are still worried about them and say they'll refuse.

So how does the law deal with people who refuse vaccinations?

And if refusing to get a jab puts others at risk in your workplace, can you be fired?



Featured:

Cecilia Anthony Das, Lecturer and Course Coordinator, School of Business and Law, Edith Cowan University, Perth

items.title: Inside Japan's nuclear disaster zone
items.content:
It's been ten years since the Fukushima nuclear disaster, but the clean-up is still in its infancy.

Today on the Signal, we're going inside what's left of the Fukushima nuclear power plant to find out how much work there is left to do, and what the plan is for more than a million tonnes of contaminated seawater.

Featured: 

Jake Sturmer, ABC North Asia Correspondent, Tokyo

items.title: How QAnon is mutating to survive
items.content:
It hasn't been an easy time for QAnon supporters.

A key prediction that Joe Biden would be hauled away in handcuffs instead of inaugurated on January 20, never came to pass.

Nevertheless, the conspiracy still has followers and now they have their sights set on a new date.

Today on The Signal, we look at how QAnon is mutating to survive.

And how its followers, including one Australian woman, are finding ways to keep believing.

Featured:

Megan, friend of a long time QAnon supporter

Travis View, QAnon Anonymous podcast

items.title: Facebook v Australia
items.content:
Facebook has adopted a drastic bargaining position in its fight with Australia, blocking news from its platform rather than agreeing to a plan to pay for local journalism.

Community groups, state health departments and even the Bureau of Meteorology have been caught out by the ban too, which came in overnight yesterday without warning.

So is this just a negotiating tactic from Facebook?

Or could it be forever?

Today on The Signal, we ask who will blink first in the showdown over the Government's media bargaining code.



Featured:

Professor Axel Bruns, Digital Media Research Centre, Queensland University of Technology, Brisbane

items.title: Why one family is still on Christmas Island
items.content:
The modern Liberal Party is very attached to its tough asylum seeker policies, because it's always been a vote winner for them.

But are there exceptions to that rule?

The case of Australia's most prominent asylum seeker family returned to court this week, and the Government lost its high profile appeal against them.

And their case has support from some unexpected parts of Australia's ideological spectrum.

The Tamil family rose to prominence after the Central Queensland town of Biloela campaigned strongly on their behalf, after their temporary settlement there was brought to an abrupt end.

Despite this week's ruling, there's no end in sight for their detention on Christmas Island.

So what’s next for the family? And what's in it for the Government to keep up this fight?
Featured:

Helen Davidson, reporter, Guardian Australia

Josh Taylor, reporter, Guardian Australia

items.title: Is Donald Trump going to jail?
items.content:
Even though Donald Trump was acquitted at his Senate impeachment trial, he isn't out of the woods yet.

The former US president is still facing allegations of rape, sexual assault, tax fraud, hush money payments and inciting a rebellion against the United States, and that's not even a full list.

So is Donald Trump going to go down?

And if he does, could he still run for president again anyway?

Featured:

Barbara McQuade, Professor, University of Michigan Law School and former US Attorney, Eastern District of Michigan



And if you've been following the story of Brittany Higgins, there's a past episode of The Signal we want to share with you.

This week, the former Liberal staffer has come forward with allegations that she was raped by a colleague in a Canberra parliamentary office in 2019.

It's just the latest in a series of awful stories about the way women in Australia's political institutions are treated.

To demonstrate the lack of progress on the issue of women's safety in these workplaces, here's an episode about another horrific story in 2018, this time in NSW Parliament.

Back then, we spoke to senior press gallery journalist Karen Middleton about her own experiences of abusive politicians, and the roots of parliament's toxic culture.





https://www.abc.net.au/radio/programs/the-signal/sexual-harassment-in-politics/10486494

items.content:

items.content:
We're used to the idea that China wants to exert its influence in Australia, but Russia's campaign to advance its own interests attracts less attention.

So what does the Kremlin want with us? And how is it trying to achieve those goals?

items.title: Scott Morrison's climate crab walk
items.content:
What a difference a single word can make.

Scott Morrison appears to be crab walking his way to a net-zero emissions target, something he now describes as "preferable" for Australia by 2050.

The comment has drawn howls of protest from the National Party backbench, where some members claim a net-zero target will kill jobs in regional Australia.

So what is the Prime Minister's grand plan?

And can he pull it off?

Featured:

David Lipson, ABC Political Reporter, Canberra

items.title: Where are all the electric cars?
items.content:
The technology keeps getting better, but Australia's electric vehicle uptake has been incredibly slow.

For most people, it's still way too expensive.

So should the Government be helping bring the cost down?

Today on The Signal, the arguments for and against electric vehicle subsidies.

And with or without them, does it add up, financially speaking, to own one yet?

Thomas, proud electric van owner

items.title: Are Australia’s dietary rules right?
items.content:
We all remember the food pyramid, but is it right for everyone?



Australia’s dietary guidelines were designed with the best of intentions, to advise us how much of what to eat.



The problem is we’re not all the same, and some doctors are arguing it’s time to make some big changes.



So should we rewrite the rules?



Featured:

Dr James Muecke, Ophthalmologist and 2020 Australian of the Year

Dr Alexandra Jones, Research fellow in food policy and law at the George Institute for Global Health

items.title: Is Russia's vaccine better than ours?
items.content:
In 1957, the Russians won the space race when they launched their satellite, Sputnik.

In 2020, they claimed they'd won a different race, launching the first mass vaccination program against COVID-19, which they named Sputnik V.

Initially, scientists were sceptical, not least because the Russians hadn't published any data about the jab, and because their rollout looked suspiciously fast.

But now that the data is in, it turns out Sputnik V looks pretty good.

So how does it measure up to Australia's options, as more and more vaccine-resistant COVID-19 strains emerge?

Featured:

Felix Light, Journalist, The Moscow Times

Hassan Vally, Associate Professor in Epidemiology, La Trobe University, Melbourne

items.title: Plan B to ban Trump from office
items.content:
Donald Trump is widely expected to be acquitted in his second impeachment trial beginning this week, but Democratic strategists have a backup plan.

There are growing expectations that the former President might be pursued using a little known section of the 14th Amendment of the US Constitution to ban him from holding office again.

Today on The Signal, what to expect from this week's trial in the US Senate, and the next chapter in his opponents' playbook.

Featured:

Bruce Ackerman, Sterling Professor of Law and Political Science, Yale University

items.title: Being 'proud' of Collingwood
items.content:
Collingwood is one of Australia's biggest, oldest and richest sporting clubs, and now it's become known for something else: a history of "distinct and egregious" racism.
Last weekend, an independent report prompted by former player Héritier Lumumba's experiences of racism at Collingwood was finally released, prompting an official apology.

But the club's President Eddie McGuire also bungled the response, saying the release of the report made him "proud".

So how did Collingwood get to this point?

And what does its racism scandal say about the AFL and Australia more broadly?

Featured:

Jack Latimore, Acting Digital Editor, NITV & Birpai-Thungutti man

items.title: Myanmar's mystery coup
items.content:
Myanmar is having a recurring nightmare.

The country has endured more years of military dictatorship than democratic rule, but this week's coup still came as a surprise.

Its leader Aung San Suu Kyi is believed to be under house arrest, and other political leaders were also detained by the military in raids on Monday.

So is this the end of Myanmar's democracy project, or will the Burmese people fight back?

Featured:

Aye Min Thant, Burmese-American journalist, Yangon

Dr Justine Chambers, Associate Director, Myanmar Research Centre, Australian National University

items.title: Where does GameStop stop?
items.content:
Three weeks ago, pretty much nobody knew about the share price of the US gaming retailer GameStop.

Now, it's making global headlines.

Thanks to a ragtag army of investors from a Reddit forum called r/WallStreetBets, GameStop's share price has risen 1,400% since the start of last month, stunning hedge funds and leaving them billions of dollars worse off.

So if a group of amateurs can bring some of the world's richest people to the brink of bankruptcy, what else could they do?

Featured:

Robert Smith, Co-Host, Planet Money podcast, US National Public Radio

items.content:

So how big a threat is he to Vladimir Putin?

items.title: Adjusting to a 3 degree world
items.content:
We've always talked about avoiding climate change, but now the Australian Government is talking about adapting to it.

With fires, floods and heatwaves getting worse all the time, the modelling suggests Australia's weather will become increasingly volatile in coming decades.

So what's Australia's new plan for weather-proofing the nation, as global warming sets in?
And could the Government's shift lead to other kinds of action on climate change too?

Featured:

Amy Remeikis, Political Correspondent, Guardian Australia

Dr Liz Hanna, Honorary Senior Fellow, Fenner School of Environment and Society, Australian National University and Chair of the Environmental Health Working Group, World Federation of Public Health Associations

items.title: What you need to know about the vaccine rollout
items.content:
Australia's first COVID-19 vaccine has been approved, but it's not here yet.

It's definitely good news, but regulatory approval wasn't the last barrier standing between us and the seamless delivery of a vaccine to every last Australian.

So where are the remaining roadblocks? And if you're not at the front of the queue, then when can you expect a jab?

items.title: Will COVID vaccines reopen the world?
items.content:
The dream of free movement is starting to seem more real, with COVID-19 vaccines being rolled out around the world.

Margaret Keenan was the first person to receive an officially approved Pfizer-BioNTech vaccine, when she got the jab in a hospital in the middle of England two weeks ago.

Since then, thousands more have followed in the UK and US, while millions more have had other COVID-19 vaccines in China and Russia.

But not all COVID-19 jabs are the same, so how will a vaccinated world work?

And what happens to you if you haven't had the jab, or can’t get access to it?

Featured:

Dr Alexandra Phelan, Assistant Professor, Georgetown University Center for Global Health Science and Security, and Adjunct Professor, Georgetown University Law Center

items.title: Why we're in the Pacific's bad books
items.content:
Across the Pacific, the climate change outlook is bleak.

The models suggest that higher average temperatures in the region will exacerbate the cyclone season, cause increasingly devastating king tides, and lead to sea level rises that will make some nations uninhabitable.

So what's being done about it?

Today on The Signal, we explore the fury some in the Pacific feel towards Australia over climate change.

What's in store for the region if the worst forecasts come to pass, and what does Australia owe its neighbours?

Featured:

Jonathan Pryke, Director, Pacific Islands Program, Lowy Institute

items.title: Australia's long journey to a treaty
items.content:
While most of Australia was distracted by a pandemic, Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people have been edging towards the long held ambition of a voice to Australian Parliament.

But there's a bigger picture.

items.title: How broken is Australia's Family Court?
items.content:
When the Whitlam Government set up the Family Court of Australia, plenty of experts said it was the global gold standard.

But 35 years on, the Federal Government says the Court is beset by red tape and delay.

A bill to merge it with the Federal Circuit Court to try to fix those problems is slowly working its way through Parliament.

So will a merger really address the Family Court’s problems, or are there deeper issues at play?

Featured:

Miranda Kaye, Senior Lecturer, Faculty of Law, University of Technology Sydney

items.title: Will renters ever be able to retire?
items.content:
In the 1950s owning your own place was the 'Australian dream', but for millions of young people in 2020 it's more like the Australian mirage.

Today on The Signal, we're looking at retirement for the younger generation.

A recent Government review has found the systems that allow us to retire, like pensions and super, are broadly sustainable, but housing affordability is the big threat.

So how important is owning your home going to be for retirement, if you're coming of age in the 21st century?

And is it worth digging into your super to achieve that goal?

Featured:

Brendan Coates, Household Finances Director, Grattan Institute, Melbourne

items.title: Pardon me, Mr President
items.content:
Donald Trump, like all US presidents, has an unfettered ability to pardon people for federal crimes.

So far in his presidency, it's a power the President has used only sparingly.

But is that about that change?

Today on The Signal, what do the individuals who've received pardons from Donald Trump have in common?

And could they be joined by more members of the Trump campaign team, some of Donald Trump's own children, and even by the President himself?

Featured:

Professor Brian Kalt, Professor of Law and Harold Norris Faculty Scholar, Michigan State University

items.title: Criminalising controlling behaviour
items.content:
An overwhelming majority of women murdered by their partners in Australia are subject beforehand to a pattern of behaviour called coercive control.

New South Wales, South Australia, Queensland and Victoria are all currently looking at ways to criminalise it.

But while advocates say it could prevent physical abuse, others argue it will be hard to get convictions, and could even misfire.

So how do coercive control laws work?

And do they make a difference for victims and survivors of domestic violence?

Featured:

Nicole Lee, abuse victim-survivor and anti-family violence activist

Jess Hill, journalist and author, 'See What You Made Me Do: Power, Control and Domestic Abuse'

items.content:
Donald Trump's son-in-law, Jared Kushner, is on one last official trip to the Middle East.

On paper, it's a peace mission, but nothing in the Middle East is ever that simple.

Today on The Signal, what exactly has the Trump Administration been trying to achieve there?

And with less than two months left on the clock, did they pull it off?

items.title: Correcting the war record
items.content:
Australia is coming to terms with a revised history of the war in Afghanistan, since an inquiry by NSW Court of Appeal judge Major General Paul Brereton found special forces unlawfully killed 39 people there.

It's brand new information that's still generating shockwaves.

But what else might be missing from the official record?

Today on The Signal, the tricky business of correcting Australia's war history.

Is there room to acknowledge both heroes and war criminals?

Featured:

Brendon Kelson, former director, Australian War Memorial 1990-1994

items.title: Did Australia just get its first treaty?
items.content:
Australia has never had a treaty with any of its Indigenous nations, but the Noongar people from WA may have just changed that.

They now have the largest native title settlement on record, covering 200,000 km and worth $1.3 billion.

Legal scholars believe it could constitute Australia's first treaty, because of the power it puts in  the Noongar people's hands.

So if it is a treaty, could more follow?

And where does that leave the national campaign for a treaty for all Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people?

Featured:

Vanessa Kickett, Chair of the South West Aboriginal Land and Seas Council

Dr Harry Hobbs, Native Title expert, University of Technology Sydney

items.title: Why Australia lost it with China
items.content:
Scott Morrison doesn't often lay into China the way he did this week.

Lately, we've been trying to mend the fence with our biggest trading partner to end a growing trade war, driven by Beijing.

But yesterday, the Prime Minister's rare display of outrage was brought on by a tweet taunting Australian soldiers over war crimes allegations.

So was it an emotional slip up, or a strategic long play?

Featured:

Bill Birtles, ABC China Correspondent

items.title: Ethiopia's peace prize winner's war
items.content:
Ethiopia's prime minister Abiy Ahmed was 2019's Nobel Peace Prize winner, but some fear he's on the way to becoming a dictator.

Over the weekend, the Ethiopian government claims it quelled an uprising in the country's northern Tigray region, scattering fighters from the Tigray People's Liberation Front to the hills.

But independently verifying what has been happening in Tigray is difficult, because the Ethiopian Government has switched off the internet and disabled phone lines there, and journalists say they've been intimidated and have had to leave the country.

So what is happening on the ground in the world's 12 most populous country?

And is Abiy Ahmed's government becoming just as brutal as its predecessors?

Featured:

Zecharias Zelalem, freelance journalist covering Ethiopia

items.title: How do prisoner swaps work?
items.content:
After 804 days in jail in Iran, Australian academic Kylie Moore-Gilbert is finally free.

The Iranian government says it's the result of a prisoner swap, but the Australian government isn't confirming anything.

So what do we know about the secretive world of prisoner exchanges?

And if Iran got what it wanted, will it lead to more hostage diplomacy?

Featured:

Dr Rodger Shanahan, Research Fellow, Lowy Institute

items.title: America's superspreading holiday
items.content:
Joe Biden will inherit a public health crisis beyond any US President's experience when he takes office on January 20th.

At the moment, there are up to 180,000 new COVID-19 infections recorded every day, and many ICUs and morgues are overwhelmed.

Holiday season, starting with Thanksgiving, is about to pour fuel on that fire, with very few restrictions on movement being enforced.

So in the dying days of the Trump presidency, how bad could the pandemic get?

And what can Joe Biden realistically do to turn it around?

Featured:

Yasmeen Abutaleb, National reporter focussing on health policy, Washington Post

items.title: Why delivery apps are deadly
items.content:
Since September, five delivery riders have died on the job in Australia, and none of their families has been entitled to compensation.

These apps have been around for years now. So why has nothing changed?

Today on The Signal, the underclass of foreign workers responding to Australia's dinner whims.

Why doesn't our legal system offer them better protections?

Featured:

Lydia Feng, Local Communities reporter, ABC News Sydney

Joellen Riley Munton, Professor of Law, University of Technology Sydney

items.title: Australia's place in the vaccine queue
items.content:
More and more COVID-19 vaccines are returning their clinical results, and it's good news.

The latest development came from the Oxford University trial with pharmaceutical company Astrazeneca, which was found to be 70% effective in participants, although that figure rose to 90% when the vaccine was administered in a different dose.

It comes hot on the heels of two other vaccine candidates returning preliminary results of 95% efficacy earlier in November.

In fact the recent results have been so promising the US, the UK and Germany are weeks away from starting to roll out vaccines to the public.

So what's the hold up in Australia?

Today on The Signal, Australia's place in the vaccine queue.

And how will the rollout go when it does happen?

Featured:

Professor Terry Nolan, Head of the Vaccine and Immunisation Research Group, Peter Doherty Institute, University of Melbourne

items.title: Australia's back road to net zero
items.content:
More and more countries are signing up to a net zero emissions target.

China, Japan and South Korea have all committed in just the past few months, while US President-elect Joe Biden will follow suit next year.

But Australia is still holding out, with Prime Minister Scott Morrison saying he won't promise a neutral emissions target by 2050 until the economic cost is clear.

So does that matter?

Or will the states, territories and private sector get Australia there anyway?

Featured:

Tim Buckley, Director of Energy Finance Studies for Australasia, Institute for Energy Economics and Financial Analysis

But really, it's just the beginning.

So what will justice look like when it arrives?

items.title: Locking down South Australia
items.content:
We've seen coronavirus lockdowns before, but this one is different.

For six days, the entire state of South Australia is under tight restrictions to buy authorities time to trace and contain a COVID-19 cluster that's spreading across Adelaide's suburbs.

They're the toughest statewide measures we've ever had in Australia, and if the lockdown all goes to plan it could be the shortest too.

So can the state pull this off?

Or will the virus spread out of control and kill Christmas?

Featured:

Adrian Esterman, Professor of Biostatistics and Epidemiology, University of South Australia

items.title: Bracing for some "brutal truths"
items.content:
Most of us don't have a clear picture of what Australia's special forces do when they're on a deployment.

In some ways, that's the whole idea, because secrecy comes with the territory.

But some of those secrets are about to get a very public airing.

Today on The Signal, the war crimes report Australia is bracing for.

How did we get here, and what comes next?

Featured:

Mark Willacy, Reporter, ABC Investigations Unit

Today on The Signal, the war crimes report Australia is bracing for.

How did we get here, and what comes next?

items.title: Has Adelaide's COVID luck run out?
items.content:
South Australia was having a charmed run against COVID-19, but on Sunday that changed.

Six weeks out from Christmas, a cluster is growing in the northern suburbs of Adelaide, with hundreds of people already in precautionary quarantine.

Family reunions have been cancelled, summer plans are in disarray, and 1.7 million South Australians are adjusting to new rules introduced last night.

So how did this happen? And how bad could it get?

Featured:

Tory Shepherd, Adelaide-based freelance journalist and columnist

items.title: Is Donald Trump staging a coup?
items.content:
Donald Trump's reaction to his election loss has people dropping the c-bomb.

It's been clear for more than a week that he lost the US election, but he still hasn’t acknowledged the fact.

On the contrary, he's actively denying it.

And he's doing some things that a President who's just lost an election, would never normally do.

He's fired a handful of top defence and intelligence officials and replaced them with loyalists.

It’s prompted speculation there's a coup of sorts in the works.

Today on The Signal, we're covering Donald Trump’s reaction to losing so far.

Is it a serious attempt to hang on to power? Or something else altogether?

Featured:

Kim Hoggard, Non-resident Fellow, US Studies Centre, University of Sydney & former senior official, Reagan Administration & Bush Snr Administration

items.title: Leaving Afghanistan behind
items.content:
While we were all watching the US election, a terrorist attack in Kabul killed 35 people.

It's just the latest attack in the country and the violence is escalating.

So why does Donald Trump want to pull out US troops?

And if troops left, what would that mean for the Afghan people?



Featured:

Kathy Gannon, Senior Correspondent for Pakistan and Afghanistan, Associated Press

items.title: Does Australia have a Murdoch problem?
items.content:
Half a million Australians, including two former prime ministers, want to see a royal commission into Rupert Murdoch's News Corp, and whether or not it's damaging to our democracy.

They're serious charges, and half a million is a lot of people.

So could it happen? And if it did, what would it actually achieve?

Featured:

Dr Denis Muller, Senior Research Fellow at the Centre for Advancing Journalism at the University of Melbourne

items.title: Does sex in Canberra matter?
items.content:
Christian Porter and Alan Tudge are the two government ministers at the centre of a ABC 4 Corners investigation.

Both men have been accused of inappropriate sexual or romantic entanglements with staffers.

Christian Porter denies it.

But there's an argument that these claims should never have seen the light of day in the first place.

Today on The Signal, we look into the story the Government tried very hard to kill.

When is knowing about a politician's sex life in the public interest? And is this one of those times?

Featured:

Louise Milligan, Reporter, ABC TV 4 Corners

items.title: What China wants
items.content:
Australia has been trying to get China to pick up the phone for more than six months, but still there’s no answer.

Over that time, China has thrown up barriers to shipments of everything from Australian lobsters to beef, timber, wine, sugar, copper and coal.

So what is China playing at?

And as the unofficial trade war drags on, is there a way out?

Featured:

Bill Birtles, ABC China Correspondent
